annotation.TEXT: The second fight with Colonel increases his speed, gives him new attacks, and makes his pattern generally a bit harder to deal with. Overall though, I still wouldn't say he's difficult to fight. His weakness is rather unconventional (since it's the Frost Tower, of all things), but you can at least get him to bump into it.
As seen here, the only real use it has is for getting two specific Heart Tanks (and later on, one particular fight where it's required - but we'll get to that soon enough).

Finally, we get Rising Fire, otherwise known as the second worst weapon in the game. Straight up is already a horrible trajectory in most Mega Man games, and with less than average damage output, this one is among the most useless in that regard.

The body section of the Fourth Armor isn't much different from ones seen in the previous games. It increases your overall defense, halving all damage you receive. Getting hit will also build meter for the Nova Strike, X's new giga attack in this game.

Twin Slasher suffers from the same problem that Soul Body does. The overall concept and functionality is just fine, but its damage output is way too low for it to be useful in most situations. Aside from weakness affiliations, it's not leaving the bench (then again, that pretty much applies to nearly every other weapon in this game).

To be honest, I usually try taking the ride armor into this fight simply because it seems to be a slightly faster way of getting into Magma Dragoon's room. On the other hand, I've never been able to beat Dragoon with the armor on the console version, for some reason. I don't know if it's just because I'm a bit more adept at this game than I was back then, or if it's just something with the PC version in general, but I actually managed to beat Dragoon with the armor even though it wasn't my initial intention to do so.
